北约领导人延斯斯托尔滕贝格周四表示，北约准备向科索沃部署更多军队，以平息北部种族两极分化的暴力事件，并补充说首批 700 名增援部队正在前往那里的途中。

“北约将保持警惕。我们将在那里确保安全和有保障的环境，同时平息和缓和紧张局势，”他在奥斯陆举行的北约外长会议间隙告诉记者。

科索沃北部的动荡局势愈演愈烈，因为阿尔巴尼亚族市长在塞族人抵制的 4 月份选举后在该地区的塞族人占多数的地区就职，此举导致美国及其盟友谴责普里什蒂纳。

周一，在 30 名驻科部队维和人员和 52 名塞族抗议者受伤后，北约决定增加 700 名士兵，以加强其在该地区 4000 人的任务。

斯托尔滕贝格称针对北约军队的暴力行为“完全不可接受”，并表示盟国正在准备更多军队，以防北约需要向该地区派遣更多增援部队。

“我们向贝尔格莱德和普里什蒂纳传达的信息是，他们必须真诚地参与欧盟推动的对话，”他补充说。

Sabine Siebold 和 Benoit Van Overstraeten 的报道； Bart Meijer 编辑; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 07:26:02 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/nato-ready-deploy-even-more-troops-quell-unrest-kosovo-stoltenberg-2023-06-01/ https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/nato-ready-deploy-even-more-troops-quell-unrest-kosovo-stoltenberg-2023-06-01/Reuters科索沃塞族/暴力斯托尔滕贝格（更新 1，电视） China's Henan plans 'zero-dyanamic' end to youth unemployment

中国河南省公布了一项“动态清除”青年失业的 100 天计划，因为人们对青年失业率创历史新高的担忧加剧，今年将有数百万学生毕业。

该计划将于5月至8月在高校开展，包括促进事业单位和国有企业就业、第二学位和基层或农村就业项目。

省教育厅本周在社交媒体上表示，目标是确保长期失业“零动态清算”和“高校毕业生顺利就业”。

“百日冲刺期间，各高校要重点摸清就业受阻、失业的重点群体毕业生人数……对他们进行一对一的指导、培训和就业输送。” ，”该部门说。

河南是中国第三大人口大省，拥有近一亿人口。

在全国范围内，随着受过教育的年轻人在摆脱三年 COVID-19 限制后仍然是世界上增长最快的主要经济体之一的工作岗位竞争，青年就业率在 4 月份达到创纪录的 20.4%。

经济学家预计，随着毕业生进入就业市场，未来几年青年失业将变得越来越普遍。但与此同时，劳动力老龄化导致的工厂劳动力短缺可能会加剧就业市场的失衡。

教育部门使用的“动态清零”一词让人想起当局在抗击 COVID 时使用的语言，反映了对失业的关注程度。

为杜绝 COVID 采取的严厉策略导致学生长时间被限制在校园内，这加剧了人们的沮丧情绪，导致 2022 年末学生罕见地抗议 COVID 政策。

近年来，受中国应届毕业生欢迎的科技、教育、房地产和金融等行业都面临监管打击。

Farah Master 的报道；北京新闻编辑室补充报道；由 Robert Birsel 编辑; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 07:18:00 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/china/chinas-henan-plans-zero-dyanamic-end-youth-unemployment-2023-06-01/ https://www.reuters.com/world/china/chinas-henan-plans-zero-dyanamic-end-youth-unemployment-2023-06-01/Farah Master中国经济/青年（PIX） Nvidia CEO feels safe relying heavily on Taiwan manufacturing

英伟达公司(NVDA.O)是人工智能芯片和计算系统的主要供应商，其首席执行官黄仁勋周四表示，对于严重依赖台湾制造感到“非常安全”。

Huang 在台北一场科技活动的间隙表示，他计划在周五会见芯片制造商台积电(2330.TW)和电子产品制造商富士康(2317.TW) 的高管。

他补充说，他还没有决定在台湾之行后是否会访问中国。

黄说，英伟达是全球最有价值的上市半导体公司，其供应链中内置了很多“多样性”和“弹性”，并将台积电在不同地区实现多元化的过程描述为一项出色的战略。

英伟达周二加入了一个由市值 1 万亿美元的美国公司组成的精英俱乐部，投资者纷纷涌入这家芯片制造商，该公司已迅速成为人工智能繁荣的最大赢家之一。

Huang 在半导体强国台湾广受欢迎，在访问台北期间受到了摇滚明星般的欢迎，他在周一发表了一个有数千人参加的主旨演讲，其中一些人在他两个小时的演讲后围着他自拍。

本·布兰查德报道；由 Anne Marie Roantree、Jacqueline Wong 和 Christina Fincher 编辑; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 07:13:51 GMT https://www.reuters.com/technology/nvidia-ceo-feels-safe-relying-heavily-taiwan-manufacturing-2023-06-01/ https://www.reuters.com/technology/nvidia-ceo-feels-safe-relying-heavily-taiwan-manufacturing-2023-06-01/Reuters英伟达台湾/（更新 1，PIX） Former Australian SAS veteran loses defamation case over reports of Afghan execution

澳大利亚最受勋的士兵之一在针对三家报纸的诽谤诉讼中败诉，这三家报纸指控他在部署期间参与谋杀了六名阿富汗人，这是一起揭开精英 SAS 秘密面纱的案件的惊人结局。

报纸证实了他们指控前 SAS 下士 Ben Roberts-Smith 的六项谋杀指控中的四项，但“根据我的结论，每项（诽谤）诉讼都必须被驳回，”联邦法院法官 Anthony Besanko 周四在悉尼表示，在他的发现总结中。

与刑事法庭相比，澳大利亚民事法庭要求的证明指控的门槛更低。罗伯茨-史密斯没有被指控犯有任何罪行。

该裁决标志着寻求对通常受保密约束的澳大利亚军方承担更大责任的媒体机构的胜利。一份 2022 年的报告发现了可靠的证据，证明澳大利亚特种空勤团 (SAS) 的成员在旷日持久的阿富汗战争中杀死了数十名手无寸铁的囚犯。

44 岁的罗伯茨-史密斯因在 2006 年至 2012 年期间六次出访阿富汗期间的行动而赢得多项最高军事荣誉（包括维多利亚十字勋章）后被视为民族英雄。

后来，他作为一名受欢迎的公共演说家和媒体主管开创了退伍军人生涯。他的肖像挂在澳大利亚战争纪念馆。

但自 2018 年以来，《悉尼先驱晨报》、《时代报》和《堪培拉时报》的文章表明，他超出了可接受的军事行动范围，包括对手无寸铁的阿富汗平民的野蛮对待。

这些文章援引其他自称当时在场的士兵的话称，罗伯茨-史密斯开枪打死了一名手无寸铁的阿富汗少年观察员，并将一名戴着手铐的男子踢下悬崖，然后下令将他枪杀。

罗伯茨-史密斯起诉报纸将他描绘成“违反军事交战的道德和法律规则”的人。他称这些报道是虚假的，并且基于嫉妒他的荣誉的失败士兵的说法，并寻求未指明的损害赔偿。

报纸试图通过证明这些说法是真实的来为他们的报道辩护，并让其他士兵和前士兵作为证人出庭证实他们的说法。

该策略在很大程度上奏效了。报纸报道称，罗伯茨-史密斯向一名军衔较低的澳大利亚士兵施压，要求他处决一名手无寸铁的阿富汗老兵，以“让新手流血”，贝桑科法官说，并补充说，他们证明了这一说法是真实的。

在另一起案件中，报纸报道说，罗伯茨-史密斯谋杀了一名有假腿的阿富汗男子，然后他“冷酷无情，不人道，以至于他将假腿带回澳大利亚，并鼓励他的士兵将其用作新奇的啤酒饮用器皿"，法官说。他说，文件证明指控也是真实的。

“对于我们新闻编辑室和我们组织中支持这项真正重要的公共利益新闻业的许多人来说，这是一个证明，”报纸所有者九号娱乐有限公司(NEC.AX)的出版总编辑詹姆斯切塞尔说。

切塞尔在法庭外说：“这是对 SAS 勇敢士兵的证明，他们为国家做出了卓越的贡献，然后有勇气说出所发生的事情的真相。”

罗伯茨 - 史密斯的律师亚瑟摩西告诉记者，“我们将考虑他的名誉作出的冗长判决，并研究与上诉有关的问题”。罗伯茨-史密斯没有出庭。

贝桑科表示，在联邦政府申请推迟诉讼程序以使政府律师有时间检查国家安全信息是否被无意泄露后，他将在周一给出他的决定的理由。

Byron Kaye 的报道 Shri Navaratnam 和 Michael Perry 编辑; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 06:42:45 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/australian-war-veteran-loses-defamation-lawsuit-over-afghan-killings-2023-06-01/ https://www.reuters.com/world/australian-war-veteran-loses-defamation-lawsuit-over-afghan-killings-2023-06-01/Byron Kaye澳大利亚法庭/战争（更新 2，PIX，电视） UK house prices slip, market to struggle with higher rates-Nationwide

抵押贷款机构 Nationwide 周四表示，英国房价在 5 月份小幅下跌，在近期借贷成本飙升后，该国的房地产市场在未来几个月面临逆风。

Nationwide 的房价指标在 4 月份环比上涨 0.4% 后，5 月份较 4 月份下跌 0.1%。

路透社调查的分析师此前预计物价环比上涨 0.1%。

Nationwide 表示，与去年 5 月相比，平均房价在 4 月下降 2.7% 后下降了 3.4%。

前总理利兹·特拉斯 (Liz Truss) 的“迷你预算”减税计划导致金融市场陷入动荡，导致去年底抵押贷款利率飙升，房地产市场在 2023 年初出现复苏迹象。

然而，上周公布的强于预期的通胀数据导致债券收益率再次上升，这反过来又促使一些贷方控制或重新定价抵押贷款。

Nationwide 首席经济学家罗伯特·加德纳 (Robert Gardner) 表示，“短期内房地产市场的逆风似乎会增强”，并指出借贷成本和抵押贷款利率可能持续上涨的风险。

“尽管如此，在我们看来，相对软着陆仍然是最有可能的结果，因为劳动力市场状况依然稳固，家庭资产负债表似乎处于相对良好的状态，”加德纳说。

William Schomberg 的报道由 Muvija M 和 Paul Sandle 编辑; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 06:21:46 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/uk-house-prices-slip-market-struggle-with-higher-rates-nationwide-2023-06-01/ https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/uk-house-prices-slip-market-struggle-with-higher-rates-nationwide-2023-06-01/Reuters英国经济/房价（更新 1） Foreigners pull more money out of China in May

5 月份外国投资者抛售中国股票的势头有所增强，原因是国内需求低迷以及对企业盈利疲弱的预期导致大陆和香港股市大幅下跌。

Refinitiv 数据显示，继 4 月份卖出 6.59 亿美元后，本月外国投资者通过沪港通卖出了价值 17.1 亿美元的大陆股票，沪港通是大陆与香港交易所之间的重要跨境联系。

此次抛售标志着他们在 1 月份总计 209.2 亿美元的巨额投资缓慢逆转，当时中国在经历了三年的 COVID 限制措施后重新开放经济，引发了一波对增长的看涨预期。

随着国内外需求萎缩，复苏不平衡，这种希望破灭了。根据国家统计局的数据，今年前四个月，中国工业企业利润大幅下滑。

尽管 2 月、4 月和 5 月出现资金流出，但今年前 5 个月外资净买入内地股票的金额仍为 250.5 亿美元，而 2022 年全年的净买入额约为 63.6 亿美元。

根据周三公布的官方采购经理人指数 (PMI) 调查，中国 5 月份制造业活动收缩幅度超过预期。 财新/标普全球制造业采购经理人指数周四发布，尽管私营部门调查显示中国工厂活动在 5 月份出人意料地从下降转为增长。

4月份，进口大幅收缩，出厂价回落，房地产投资低迷，工业利润大幅下滑，工业产值和零售额均低于预期。

过去一个月，分析师将中国大中型企业未来 12 个月的盈利预测下调了 0.7% 以上，其中矿业和房地产行业下调了 3% 以上。

abrdn 亚洲股票高级投资总监 Pruksa Iamthongthong 表示：“消费者和企业投资者的信心没有像市场希望的那样迅速恢复。”

“我们认为经济需要时间才能复苏，我们将在短期内看到一段避险情绪，以应对全球经济潜在衰退背景下经济活动放缓带来的风险。”

据晨星公司称，在 1 月份流入 25 亿美元之后，专门投资于中国大陆、台湾和香港的美国基金在 2 月至 4 月期间流出 11.5 亿美元。

截至 5 月 25 日当周，安联全中国股票 WT（英镑）流出 1.376 亿美元，创下至少自 2018 年 7 月以来的最大单周流出量，而 iShares Core MSCI 中国 ETF（港元） （2801.HK）面临 1.0372 亿美元净卖出价值，如 Refinitiv 所示。

上证综指(.SSEC) 5 月份下跌 3.6%，创下七个月来的最大单月跌幅，而 MSCI 亚太指数(.MIAP00000PUS)的跌幅为 1.2%。

“需要采取果断的政策行动，包括周期性和宏观政策工具，例如下调存款准备金率和有针对性的财政宽松政策，以恢复信心，尽管从长远来看，投资者可能对中国经济过于悲观，并且已经消化了太多的风险或下行空间，”汇丰资产管理主动股票全球能力主管亚历山大戴维说。

随着美联储提高利率以应对通胀压力，投资者变得更加厌恶风险，中国股市也出现资金外流。

M&G Investments 亚洲股票投资组合经理 Vikas Pershad 表示，由于中国各个行业的监管审查力度加大，中国市场的风险溢价有所增加，投资者需要更高的回报才能将更多资金配置到该市场。

Pershad 说：“外国投资者似乎一直在抛售，因为近期经济数据不佳，也许是因为具有更广泛（泛亚或全球）授权的投资者可以获得机会。”

“我们假设其他投资者今年已经将一些资本从中国重新分配到这些市场（和其他市场）。”

Patturaja Murugaboopathy 和 Gaurav Dogra 在班加罗尔的报道； Vidya Ranganathan 和 Simon Cameron-Moore 编辑; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 06:18:59 GMT https://www.reuters.com/world/china/foreigners-pull-more-money-out-china-may-2023-06-01/ https://www.reuters.com/world/china/foreigners-pull-more-money-out-china-may-2023-06-01/Patturaja Murugaboopathy, Gaurav Dogra中国市场/流量（图形） Analysis: Remaining Western firms face tricky Russian exits

经过数月的谈判，芬兰的诺记轮胎公司（TYRES.HE）即将于去年底敲定以 4 亿欧元（4.4032 亿美元）出售其俄罗斯业务的交易。然后莫斯科再次改变了规则。

去年 12 月，政府要求离开俄罗斯的公司以至少一半的价格出售其业务，并要求将销售额的 10% 用于联邦预算，美国财政部称之为“退出税”。

诺记轮胎将与俄罗斯石油巨头 Tatneft (TATN.MM)的商定销售价格降至2.86 亿欧元，最终在启动“受控退出”九个月后于 3 月获得了监督外国投资的政府委员会的批准。

诺记轮胎的长期撤离表明尚未完全撤离该国的西方公司面临越来越大的阻力。在莫斯科入侵乌克兰引发大规模外流 15 个月后，仍留在当地的公司面临着越来越大的不确定性。

“战争以一种快速且不可预测的方式改变了经营环境，”诺记轮胎公司的首席转型官 Johanna Horsma 告诉路透社。 “9 月和 12 月俄罗斯法规的新变化产生了重大影响。”

去年，由于西方政府实施制裁，从电信公司到时装零售商，数千家公司停止了在俄罗斯的业务。

一些人设法通过谈判迅速退出，通常以大幅折扣出售或将钥匙交给当地管理层。

退出的步伐现在已经大幅放缓，但对于那些留下来的人来说，规则更难驾驭。

通过总统令将资产国有化——一个持续的威胁——在 4 月份被利用，没收了芬兰的 Fortum (FORTUM.HE)和德国的 Uniper (UN01.DE)拥有的资产。

未知

法兰克福 Baker McKenzie 的合伙人 Peter Wand 博士说，获得政府委员会的批准非常苛刻、耗时且困难，他曾参与 Nokian Tyres 的退出。

他说，评估过程需要俄罗斯对企业进行评估，这一过程特别漫长，因为不断收紧的制裁制度要求不断进行合规检查。

“从西方的角度来看，你会期望更多的血肉之躯描述过程和最后期限，”Wand 说。他补充说，在 12 月中旬公布的额外估值要求是在诺记轮胎交易的中期。

挪威包装公司 Elopak (ELO.OL)的首席执行官 Thomas Kormendi 于 3 月完成了将其俄罗斯业务出售给当地管理层的交易，费用未公开，他表示“未知”是最重要的问题。

R.Politik 分析公司的创始人塔蒂亚娜·斯塔诺瓦亚 (Tatiana Stanovaya) 表示，公司与政府的关系至关重要。

Kormendi 将国有化描述为任何公司的“最糟糕的噩梦”，他说 Elopak 已同意一项为期六年的回购条款，反映了许多退出公司所做的交易。

Baker McKenzie's Wand 警告说，留给剩下的人的时间已经不多了。

“如果你不能及时出售，那么你可能没有足够的现金来继续经营，”他说。 “对于那些仍在俄罗斯的人来说，时间过得很快。”

分析人士周四表示，朝鲜最新的太空发射器似乎是一种新设计，很可能使用为该核武器国家的洲际弹道导弹 (ICBM) 开发的发动机。

这枚被称为 Chollima-1 的火箭在周三的首次发射尝试中失败了。据官方媒体报道，它成功升空，但第二阶段未能按预期启动，坠入黄海。

尽管失败了，官方媒体还是罕见地发布了火箭升空的照片，让国际分析人士第一次看到了这种新发射器。

美国卡内基国际和平基金会的 Ankit Panda 说：“我们看到的这款运载火箭的设计起源与旧的 Unha 系列太空运载火箭完全不同。” “它似乎使用了早期朝鲜洲际弹道导弹中出现的发动机。”

国际战略研究所的国防研究员约瑟夫·登普西 (Joseph Dempsey) 也得出结论，该火箭可能由安装在朝鲜 Hwasong-15 洲际导弹上的双喷嘴液体燃料发动机提供动力。

一些专家认为该发动机源自苏联 RD-250 系列发动机，而早期的银河太空发射器则使用源自飞毛腿导弹的发动机组。

“虽然 Chollima-1 的废气羽流看起来是透明的，表明它是液体燃料，但它确实在发射台周围、火焰桶的出口和附近的泥滩上沉积了浅灰色的残留物，”总部位于美国的 38 North 监测朝鲜在一份报告中说。 “这种残留的原因尚不清楚。”

美国和其他国家表示，将弹道导弹技术用于太空发射违反了联合国安理会禁止朝鲜导弹和核武器计划的决议。

Panda 说，与上一次朝鲜在 2016 年尝试发射卫星不同，它拥有强大的洲际弹道导弹计划，不需要将其武器试验伪装成太空发射。

Chollima-1 似乎是一种中型运载火箭，用于将小型卫星送入近地轨道。

“在这种情况下，与早期的朝鲜太空运载火箭相比，我们确实有一个相当大的有效载荷整流罩，”Panda 说。 “我的估计是，这可能携带一颗质量约为 200 至 300 公斤的卫星有效载荷。”

他补充说，朝鲜宣称的最终能够用一枚火箭发射多颗卫星的目标表明，他们可能会在未来推出更大的运载火箭。

韩国表示，它正在努力回收朝鲜火箭的部件，并发布了一些照片，这些照片显示分析人士称，这似乎是一个设计用于连接两个级的部分，以及内部的液体推进剂罐。

韩国军方表示，周四继续开展恢复行动，派遣了更多的专业船只。

Panda 说，如果韩国设法从水中打捞出火箭的主要部件，它可以为朝鲜的火箭和导弹生产提供有用的情报，特别是它可能使用的任何外国材料。

“我们越来越相信，朝鲜在制造机身方面已基本实现自给自足，主要制造其发动机的许多结构部件，但朝鲜仍有可能从海外进口一些部件，”他说。

随着基辅准备使用最近获得的西方武器进行反攻，试图赶走俄罗斯占领者，峰会的大部分焦点将集中在乌克兰身上。

Foreign ministers from the BRICS countries are meeting in South Africa from Thursday as the five-nation bloc seeks to forge itself into a counterweight to Western geopolitical dominance in the wake of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

The talks are a prelude to an August summit in Johannesburg that has already created controversy because of the possible attendance of Russian President Vladimir Putin, the target of an International Criminal Court (ICC) arrest warrant.

It accused him in March of the war crime of forcibly deporting children from Russian-occupied territory in Ukraine.莫斯科否认这些指控。 South Africa had already invited Putin in January.

South African authorities confirmed that foreign ministers from Brazil, Russia, India, and South Africa are attending Thursday's meeting in Cape Town. A deputy minister is representing China.

No agenda has been made public, but analysts said discussions would aim to deepen ties among existing members and consider an expansion of the group.

"BRICS is positioning itself as an alternative to the West and as a way to make space for emerging powers," said Cobus van Staden of the South African Institute of International Affairs.

Once viewed as a loose, largely symbolic association of disparate emerging economies, BRICS has in recent years taken more concrete shape, driven initially by Beijing and, since the start of the Ukraine war in February 2022, with added impetus from Moscow.

Discussions of BRICS' New Development Bank, which stopped funding projects in Russia to comply with sanctions, were expected on Thursday, a South African foreign ministry source said.

COULD OIL PRODUCERS JOIN?

Amid the growing geopolitical polarisation resulting from the war in Ukraine, BRICS leaders have said they are open to admitting new members, including oil producing countries.

Venezuela, Argentina, Iran, Algeria, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates are on a list of those who have either formally applied to join or expressed interest, officials said.

"If they can bring in the oil producer countries that will be key, given the petrodollar system," said William Gumede, a South African political analyst who has written extensively on BRICS.

South Africa, though the bloc's smallest member, is among its biggest champions.

Its preparations for the Aug. 22-24 summit, however, have been complicated by the ICC announcement on Putin.

As an ICC member South Africa would face pressure to arrest Putin, were he to attend the meeting in Johannesburg.

Putin has not confirmed his plans, with the Kremlin only saying Russia would take part at the "proper level".

South Africa's position is unclear. Pretoria has said it will honour its obligations under its ICC membership, but the government is still weighing the possibility of hosting Putin or even moving the summit to China.

Independent political analyst Nic Borain said the government was caught between its support for BRICS and friendship with Russia on one side and the looming backlash from vital Western economic partners on the other.

"Obviously, the best solution for South Africa is if Putin decided not to come."

Tensions between the United States and China are expected to loom over Asia's top security meeting this week, as China has declined a bilateral meeting between the superpowers' defence chiefs.

The Shangri-La Dialogue, which attracts top defence officials, senior military officers, diplomats, weapons makers and security analysts from around the globe, will take place June 2-4 in Singapore.

More than 600 delegates from 49 countries will attend the meeting, which opens with a keynote address by Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.

Analysts say the dialogue is invaluable for the many bilateral and multilateral military-to-military meetings held on the sidelines of plenary sessions and speeches delivered by defence ministers.

China's new Defence Minister Li Shangfu, however, has declined to meet US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin, the Pentagon said on Monday.

China's defence ministry spokesperson said in response to a query at a news conference in Beijing that exchanges between the two militaries have always been ongoing but that the US was "entirely to blame" for current difficulties.

"On the one hand, the US keeps saying that it wants to strengthen communication, but on the other hand, it ignores China's concerns and artificially creates obstacles, seriously undermining the mutual trust between the two militaries," said the spokesperson, without saying what the obstacles were.

Russia's war in Ukraine, tensions between China and Taiwan and North Korea's weapons programmes will also be high on the agenda of many delegates, analysts said. No Russian or North Korean government delegates will attend the meeting.

Some regional diplomats and defence analysts said they will be watching the performance of General Li, who was named China's new defence minister in March and was sanctioned by the US in 2018 over weapons purchases from Russia.

Although the defence minister is a largely diplomatic and ceremonial post within the Chinese system, Li serves on the powerful Central Military Commission under President Xi Jinping and is close to his key military ally, Zhang Youxia, they said.

Drew Thompson, a visiting senior research fellow at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy at the National University of Singapore (NUS), said the snub to the US was most likely Xi's decision.

"The reality is that General Li is coming with a set of instructions to paint the US in a very negative light rather than a set of instructions to engage in dialogue to improve and stabilise the relationship and that is unfortunate," Thompson said.

NUS political scientist Chong Ja Ian said the lack of a formal bilateral meeting does not mean the two countries will not have contact.

"I'm sure they will go at each other during the plenary sessions, then there are the breakouts and possible informal conversations," he said.

Lynn Kuok, a senior fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies - the think tank that organises the Shangri-La Dialogue - said she was not optimistic about US-China relations improving.

"What we really need to be focused on here, however, are guard rails to prevent competition from spiralling into open conflicts, but I think China is also suspicious of that (the guard rails)," Kuok said.

Other key issues that are likely to be discussed include ongoing tensions in the disputed South China Sea and East China Seas.

The evolving security relationships of AUKUS, which tightens ties between the US, Britain and Australia, as well as the Quad grouping of the US, Japan, India and Australia are also expected to feature, particularly given China's concerns that the groupings are an attempt to encircle China.

Like a rising number of her highly educated peers, Liang keeps trading down to try and find a source of income in China's worst youth job market on record.

"Finding a job has been really difficult," said the 25-year-old, who lives with her parents in the northern industrial city of Taiyuan. "I told my family that I'm willing to take up manual labour and my mum straight-up cried. She felt so sorry for me."

Economists expect such examples to become increasingly common in coming years, as a glut of university graduates and a shortage of factory labour due to an ageing workforce deepen China's job market imbalances .

Youth unemployment hit a record 20.4% in April, and a new high of 11.58 million university students are due to graduate this summer.

All are competing for jobs in what remains one of the world's fastest-growing major economies, but whose manufacturing-heavy structure is increasingly out of step with the aspirations of its younger generations .

The industries most popular among fresh Chinese graduates, such as tech, education, real estate and finance, have all faced regulatory crackdowns in recent years. Some of the measures have been rolled back, but business sentiment has been slow to recover: private investment rose only 0.4% in January-April, while state investment rose 9.4%.

"China's education raced ahead of the economy, which means that more diplomas were handed out than were needed by a manufacturing-based economy," said Keyu Jin, author of 'The New China Playbook', which documents the country's economic ascent.

"There's a big mismatch between expectations and the reality of the economic circumstances."

'ROLL UP YOUR SLEEVES'

It is unclear exactly how many graduates are taking jobs below their skill level, but state media has acknowledged the trend. State media editorials have encouraged young graduates to "roll up their sleeves" and by profiling a woman in her 20s who became a refuse collector after a brief stint as an accountant.

President Xi Jinping repeatedly exhorted young people to "seek hardships" in a recent state media article emphasising his suffering during the Cultural Revolution. But the message hardly resonates with today's youth who take prosperity for granted.

China's education and human resources ministries did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

Beijing has urged state-owned enterprises to recruit more graduates and began to expand vocational training schools to fill shortages in advanced manufacturing. Some local governments, including Shanghai, are offering employment subsidies for firms hiring 2023 graduates. Others have gone on a hiring spree themselves.

The service industries at the forefront of China's post-pandemic recovery offer few high-skilled roles.

"Many white-collar service positions have vanished", said Chim Lee, an analyst at the Economist Intelligence Unit.

"Jobs being created are predominantly in areas not requiring higher education, such as catering and tourism."

'TIRED OF IT'

On platforms like Xiaohongshu, China's equivalent of Instagram, some graduates tout the joys of "taking off the scholar's long gown " and avoiding China Inc's notorious "996" schedule of working from 9.00 am to 9.00 pm, six days a week.

"Young people no longer believe that someone's value comes from studying hard or career success," said Han Zhaoxue, a 26-year-old public administration master's graduate who now co-runs a rural homestay after rejecting low-paid offers.

Programming graduate Wang, 23, earns less than 3,000 yuan ($420) per month delivering food part-time in the eastern city of Jining.

"The threshold for entering the programming industry continues to rise. I couldn't find jobs at major tech firms and hated working unpaid overtime during my internship at a small firm," said Wang, giving only his surname for privacy reasons.

"I was really tired of it so moved back to my hometown," he said, adding he is now studying for the civil servant exam .

Liang, the applied maths graduate, is still unemployed and "seriously considering" hawking .

"I can't think of any more industries that I haven't applied for," she said.

The UN has proposed that Kyiv, Moscow and Ankara start preparatory work for the transit of Russian ammonia through Ukraine as it tries to salvage a deal allowing safe Black Sea grain exports, a source close to the talks said on Wednesday.

As the preparatory work starts, the UN wants parallel talks to be held on widening the Black Sea deal that was agreed last July to include more Ukrainian ports and other cargoes, said the source, who spoke to Reuters on condition of anonymity.

Russia agreed this month to a two-month extension of the deal but has said the initiative will cease unless an agreement aimed at overcoming obstacles to Russian grain and fertiliser exports is fulfilled.

Ukraine and Turkey have agreed to the new proposal, intended to improve operations in the Black Sea grain export corridor, but Russia has not yet responded, the source said.

UN spokesperson Stephane Dujarric, asked about the Reuters report at a daily press briefing, said conversations were continuing.

"As you recall, the Secretary General had put forward some ideas to the parties to improve the facilitation of the work of the Joint Coordination Centre, to also work on the issue of ammonia export, which is part of the deal that was signed. Those conversations and contacts are continuing. But that's as much as I'll say right now," Dujarric said.

The UN and Turkey brokered the Black Sea Grain Initiative between Moscow and Kyiv last July to help tackle a global food crisis aggravated by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, a leading global grain exporter.

APPEAL TO IMPROVE GRAIN CORRIDOR

The UN has handed "an official appeal to the leaders of Ukraine, Turkey and Russia with a proposal for a specific mutually beneficial algorithm to radically improve" the work of the grain corridor, the source told Reuters.

"Ukraine and Turkey have confirmed their readiness to work on the algorithm proposed by the Secretary General. At the same time, as of May 30, Russia has not given its consent, despite the presence of favourable positions in the algorithm."

Ukrainian officials have said that since mid-April, Russia has "unreasonably restricted" the work of the Black Sea grain deal.

Russia has denied this and urged all parties to unblock the transit of ammonia via the Ukrainian port of Pivdennyi, near the Black Sea port of Odesa, which was halted after Russia's invasion in February last year.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy, in his nightly video address, accused Russia of blocking all activity at Pivdennyi, with 1.5 million tonnes of agricultural products unable to move. Other countries, he said, should take note.

"All maritime countries can now see what can threaten their ports, their coastlines if Russia gets away with blocking navigation in the Black Sea," Zelenskiy said.

"In other words, the blockade of one port in Ukraine poses extremely serious risks for different nations, particularly those with relations that Russia tries to use for speculative purposes."

Ukrainian authorities have said workers would need about 30 days to prepare the pipeline to pump ammonia again.

Ukraine's deputy renovation minister said on Tuesday that Kyiv was seeking guarantees from Moscow and the UN that the grain deal will work normally if Ukraine allows Russia to export ammonia via the pipeline.

A senior government source told Reuters this month that Kyiv would consider allowing Russian ammonia to transit its territory for export on condition that the Black Sea grain deal is expanded to include more Ukrainian ports and a wider range of commodities.

South Africa is mulling its options over an International Criminal Court (ICC) arrest warrant for Russian President Vladimir Putin should he accept an invitation to a BRICS summit in August, a government official said on Wednesday.

A member of the ICC, South Africa would theoretically be required to arrest Putin under the warrant issued in March by the court, which accused him of the war crime of forcibly deporting children from Russian-occupied territory in Ukraine.

莫斯科否认这些指控。

However, South Africa had on Jan. 25 already invited Putin to the Aug. 22-24 meeting in Johannesburg of BRICS leaders of emerging economies, comprising Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa.

"There has been no firm decision," said Zane Dangor, director-general of the department of international relations, adding that ministers assigned to the matter would soon meet to consider a report setting out the options.

One option gaining traction among South African officials would be to ask the group's previous chair China to host the summit, said a senior government official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Asked whether Putin would attend the gathering, the Kremlin said on Tuesday that Russia would take part at the "proper level".

Former President Thabo Mbeki, whose views on international relations hold a lot of sway among government officials, said in a May 25 interview with radio station 702 that the summit was unlikely to take place in South Africa.

"Because of our legal obligations, we have to arrest President Putin, but we can't do that," Mbeki said.

A deputy minister, Obed Bapela, told Britain's BBC on Tuesday that South Africa was planning to pass legislation that would give Pretoria the option to decide whether or not to arrest leaders wanted by the ICC.

Bapela did not respond to requests for comment. However, a justice department official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said there wouldn't be enough time to get such a law approved by parliament before the summit.

South Africa on Monday issued diplomatic immunity to all leaders attending the meeting and a gathering of BRICS foreign ministers in Cape Town this week. The international relations department said this was standard procedure, however, for all international conferences in South Africa.

"These immunities do not override any warrant that may have been issued by any international tribunal against any attendee of the conference," department spokesperson Clayson Monyela said.

South Africa previously signalled its intention to withdraw from the ICC following protests about its failure to arrest Sudan's former president Omar al-Bashir, wanted on genocide charges, when he attended an African Union summit in Johannesburg in 2015.

The governing African National Congress decided in December that South Africa should abandon the process and try to effect changes to the ICC from within.

美国众议院定于周三就一项提高政府债务上限的法案进行表决，这是避免下周初在国会不采取行动的情况下可能出现的破坏经济稳定的违约的关键一步。

共和党人以 222 票对 213 票的微弱多数控制着众议院，但两党达成的协议需要议长凯文麦卡锡领导的共和党人和总统乔拜登领导的民主党人的支持才能通过，因为双方成员都反对该法案的重要部分。

周二晚些时候，众议院规则委员会在对有争议的立法进行的第一次程序性投票中，批准了周三在众议院全体辩论的措施。预计当天晚些时候全体众议院将对通过该法案进行表决。

委员会以 7 票对 6 票通过了这项两党协议，两名极右翼共和党人和所有四名民主党人都反对。

民主党的坚定反对并不一定表明由 213 名成员组成的政党核心小组将如何对该法案本身进行投票。

该立法将暂停美国债务上限至 2025 年 1 月 1 日，允许拜登和立法者将政治风险问题搁置到 2024 年 11 月总统大选之后。

它还将限制未来两年的一些政府支出，加快一些能源项目的许可程序，收回未使用的 COVID-19 资金，并将食品援助计划的工作要求扩大到更多的接受者。

财政部警告说，如果国会不提高限额，它将无法在 6 月 5 日之前支付政府的所有义务。

在众议院规则委员会周二的辩论中，共和党代表奇普罗伊抱怨说，没有像许多保守派所希望的那样实现更多的预算节省。他补充说，该法案也未能扭转拜登政府具有里程碑意义的成就，包括大力支出以应对气候变化的影响。

“这到底有什么好处，”罗伊说。

但反映出党派分歧，众议员艾琳·胡钦反驳说，尽管民主党控制着白宫和参议院，但该法案将实现共和党大幅削减开支。 “我们肯定是在超负荷工作，”她告诉她的众议院共和党同僚。

周二晚些时候，无党派国会预算办公室表示，该立法将在十年内节省 1.5 万亿美元。

参议员坚定立场

与此同时，参议员们正在巩固他们的立场，共和党人米特罗姆尼告诉记者他支持这笔交易，他曾与之交谈过的其他人也是如此。

“当我八岁的时候，我没有得到所有我可能希望得到的圣诞礼物，但我得到的比我预期的要多，”他说，暗指拜登和麦卡锡达成的妥协。

参议院民主党第二号人物迪克·德宾 (Dick Durbin) 表示，他仍在研究该法案的细节。他告诉记者，他特别担心这会损害美国国立卫生研究院的重要研究，他称之为“世界一流的医学研究机构”。

作为拜登的主要谈判代表之一的白宫预算主任莎兰达·扬敦促国会通过该法案。

“我想明确一点：这项协议代表了一种妥协，这意味着没有人能得到他们想要的一切，必须做出艰难的选择，”杨在新闻发布会上说。

如果众议院投票成功，该法案将提交给参议院，在那里辩论和投票可能会持续到周末，尤其是如果 100 名参议员中有任何一位试图延缓该法案的通过。

为了共和党人的胜利，该法案将从国税局转移一些资金，尽管白宫表示这不应削弱税收执法。

拜登也可以指出收益。

这笔交易使拜登标志性的基础设施和绿色能源法基本完好无损，而且开支削减和工作要求远低于共和党人所寻求的。

共和党人认为，大幅削减开支对于遏制国债增长是必要的，国债规模为 31.4 万亿美元，大致相当于经济的年产出。

根据政府预测，随着人口老龄化推高健康和退休成本，这些债务的利息支付预计将占用越来越大的预算份额。这笔交易不会对控制那些快速增长的项目起到任何作用。

大部分储蓄将通过限制住房、教育、科学研究和其他形式的“可自由支配”支出等国内项目的支出来实现。军费开支将被允许在未来两年内增加。

债务上限的僵局促使评级机构警告称，他们可能会下调支撑全球金融体系的美国债务评级。

美国上一次如此接近违约是在 2011 年，当时华盛顿存在类似的党派分歧，民主党总统和参议院占多数，共和党占众议院多数。
